body.p: Hopkinsville, Kentucky, attorney, politician, and soldier. Caroline County, Virginia, native. Son of James Buckner and Lucy Madison Buckner. Married to Gabriella Lewis Hawkins Buckner. Father of Gabriel Lewis Buckner, Lucy M. Buckner, and James F. Buckner, Jr. Graduate of Transylvania Law School in Lexington, Kentucky, in 1836. Represented Christian County in the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Kentucky from 1839 to 1847. Delegate to the Whig convention at Baltimore, Maryland in 1844 and nominated Henry Clay for the U.S. presidency. Speaker of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Kentucky in 1847. Represented Christian County in the Senate of the Commonwealth of Kentucky from 1848 to 1859. Owned nine enslaved persons in Christian County in 1850. Owned sixty-one enslaved persons in Hopkinsville in 1860. Hired three enslaved persons to Samuel L. Salter in Christian County in 1860. Elected Colonel of unorganized recruits for the United States Army near Hopkinsville, Kentucky, in August 1861. Captured by the Confederate States Army in September 1861.
